awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Digital Safety Immersion for Elementary School Students
awd_abstract_narration:
With increased access to digital devices, children have started to create digital footprints and online identities, with associated risks to their security and privacy. Fostering and facilitating the dynamics of healthy online behaviors, conflict and identity is relevant to producing responsible 21st-century learners in our schools and communities. There is a critical need to develop educational materials and research around experiences emphasizing digital safety for elementary school students. The outcome of this project has the potential to greatly improve digital safety for children without restricting their learning opportunities. This project will also provide undergraduate and graduate students in computing and education majors with the opportunity to gain experience by involving them in the design of the educational materials as well as the evaluation and research activities. The implementation of security education for elementary school grades will promote modernization of digital safety educational materials and help elementary schools adapt to technology development and prepare responsible 21st century learners.

This project addresses the need for digital safety and privacy education at the elementary school level. To accomplish this goal the project will design a comprehensive suite of digital safety educational materials for elementary school students in Grades 3-5. Topics will include cyberbullying,  digital security and privacy, footprint, and the correct way of communicating on the Internet. The materials will be disseminated to students by training 40 elementary school in-service and pre-service teachers through workshops in the greater Charlotte, North Carolina area. Week-long digital safety summer camps will reach 400 elementary school students  and will be used to conduct thorough evaluation and improvement of the educational materials. The project will also engage parents through a Parent workshop and will explore the formation of a Student-Parent-Teacher-Researcher coalition for future digital safety education.  In addition, the project proposes to apply a train-the-trainer model to ensure the materials reach a wide range of end users.  Thus, trained in-service teachers will be equipped to train other teachers and students in their schools. 

This project is supported by the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which funds proposals that address cybersecurity and privacy, and in this case specifically cybersecurity education. The SaTC program aligns with the Federal Cybersecurity Research and Development Strategic Plan and the National Privacy Research Strategy to protect and preserve the growing social and economic benefits of cyber systems while ensuring security and privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
SaTC: EDU: Digital Safety Immersion for Elementary School Students was a three-year, $399,999 National Science Foundation (NSF) grant. The goal of this grant was to address the need for digital safety education for elementary school teachers and learners. To accomplish this goal the project designed a comprehensive suite of digital safety educational materials for elementary school students in Grades 3-5. Topics included cyberbullying, digital security and privacy, footprint, and netiquette to educate responsible online behavior. The NSF grant (2015554) was awarded in 2020 to a team from University of North Carolina at Charlotte and then transferred to North Carolina State University (2319015) when the PI changed institutions. 

The project objectives were to: 1) Design a comprehensive suite of digital safety education materials for elementary school students that include cyberbullying, digital security and privacy, footprint, and netiquette to educate responsible online behavior in Grades 3 to 5; 2) Train 40 elementary school inservice and preservice teachers through workshops to disseminate the materials to students in the greater Charlotte area; 3) Conduct thorough evaluation and improvement of the educational material through digital safety summer camp with 400 elementary school students; 4) Apply the train-the-trainer model by which the in-service teachers will train the teachers or students in their school so that the proposed materials can reach a wide range of end users; and 5) Design and Deliver a Parent workshop and explore the formation of a Student-Parent-Teacher-Researcher coalition for future digital safety education for elementary school students.

Project Outcomes: Digital safety education for elementary teachers and learners is an area of need and was shown in the needs assessment studies with parents (Martin et al., 2021) and educators (Bacak et al., 2022; Martin et al., 2023). This project bridged this gap by developing teacher professional development and digital safety curriculum for elementary learners. 190 students were introduced to the curriculum through summer camps and 220 students participated in digital safety lessons when teachers implemented the digital safety modules in their classrooms. Twenty-six teachers were trained to facilitate the curriculum with the elementary students. Twenty parents also participated in workshops to learn about digital safety. 

Elementary teachers showed strong motivation, recognizing the importance of continuous digital safety education and appreciating the opportunities for collaboration and self-reflection, as indicated by the survey and interview results. Digital safety immersion summer camps had a positive impact on elementary school students, as evidenced by the achievement, attitude, and behavior data collected. Posttest scores showed a statistically significant improvement compared to pre-test results. Among the topics, cyberbullying had the highest pre- and post-camp knowledge scores, while netiquette, online behavior, and digital security and privacy scored lower in comparison. Students expressed positive attitudes in the post-camp survey, and they incorporated key lessons from the camp into the Pixton comic strips they created as part of their final project. All the project objectives were met though COVID-19 did impact the summer camp implementation in 2021 and we had to scale down the number of students who we had initially planned to reach due to social distancing. 

Project Team: During the development and delivery, researchers in both domains of cybersecurity and education collaborated closely. Cybersecurity education faculty member learned how to adapt the materials for younger audiences who face cybersecurity challenges, while educational faculty learn how to integrate the latest advances in cybersecurity for elementary school learners and teachers. As a result of these objectives, the project provided research opportunities to project team members and graduate students and educational opportunities to graduate students, elementary school students and teachers.

Student Curriculum and Teacher Professional Development Access: The digital safety curriculum is available online at https://dsc.charlotte.edu/curriculum/ for easy access and use. The teacher PD link resources are housed in the Canvas Learning Management System and can be accessed by emailing the PI. 

Research: Five publications in Educational Media International (2 articles), Computers in the Schools, Tech Trends, and Journal of Technology and Teacher Education resulted from this project. In addition, eight presentations highlighted the results from this project to a broad audience in Teacher Education, Educational Technology and Cybersecurity. The details of the research activities can be accessed at  https://dsc.charlotte.edu/research/
